tic, travis and usethis - an overview

Patrick Schratz, Kirill Müller

Source: vignettes/tic-usethis-travis.Rmd
tic-usethis-travis.Rmd

You may be a bit confused about all the different packages and their specific scopes in the world of R package development. The three packages can be arranged in the following structure, from the outer to the inner level:

usethis -> tic -> travis

The usethis package holds all the utility wrapper functions to simplify R package development. From cloning a Github repo create_from_github() over using roxygen2 for documentation (use_roxygen()) to setting up CI for your package (use_ci()). The latter function effectively calls a mixture of travis and tic functions that do the work in the background. Most of the stuff that needs to be done for Travis is handled by the travis package. These are tasks like enabling the repo in travis-ci.org, setting up ssh deployment keys for your repo on Travis and others.

After everything is ready, usethis and travis have done their jobs and the rest of the work goes to tic. By this we mean the handling of the actual CI workflow: What commands are going to be executed at all, which stage runs a specific command, how is the deployment handled.

So in summary, the three packages can be described like this:

usethis: Package holding utility wrapper functions to simplify R package development travis: Responsible for setting up all CI related stuff and taking care of permissions tic: Package to specify the CI workflow (which stages are run, which commands are used)

Developed by Kirill Müller, Mika Braginsky, Karthik Ram, Jeroen Ooms, Patrick Schratz, rOpenSci.

Site built with pkgdown 1.2.0.
